{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} [[File:72MM 14 DominicJames 2550 (a).jpg|thumb|The model [[David Gandy]] wearing a bespoke suit by Henry Poole & Co (2014)]]
'''Savile Row tailoring''' is traditional and modern, men and women's [[bespoke tailoring]] that takes place on [[Savile Row]] and neighbouring streets in [[Mayfair]], [[Central London]]. In 1846, [[Henry Poole & Co|Henry Poole]], credited as being the "Founder of Savile Row", opened an entrance to his tailoring premises into No. 32 Savile Row.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0CEFD61530F936A1575BC0A960958260&pagewanted=all |title=Savile Row's Ambassador to the Court of Kings |accessdate=9 January 2009 |author=Paula Deitz |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 August 1996}}</ref> The term "bespoke" is understood to have originated in Savile Row when cloth for a suit was said to "be spoken for" by individual customers.<ref name="BusinessWeek1">{{Cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/oct2006/gb20061030_512497.htm| title=Savile Row Never Goes Out of Style |accessdate=9 January 2009 |last=Norton |first=Kate |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=31 October 2006}}</ref> The short street has been termed the "golden mile of tailoring", where customers have included [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], [[Jude Law]], [[Winston Churchill]], [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]], [[Laurence Olivier]], [[Duke Ellington]], [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]] and [[Napoleon III]].<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="BusinessWeek1"/><ref name=BusinessWeek2>{{Cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/03_15/b3825629.htm |title=The Battle for Savile Row |accessdate=9 January 2009 |last=Dunn |first=Bill |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=14 April 2003}}</ref>
In 1969, Nutters of Savile Row modernised the style and approach of the traditional tailors; a modernisation which continued in the 1990s with the arrival of designers including [[Richard James (tailor)|Richard James]], [[Ozwald Boateng]] and [[Timothy Everest]]. With increasing rents the number of tailoring businesses on Savile Row had declined to 19 by 2006.<ref name=SRT_Westminster_Plan>{{cite web| title=Bespoke Tailoring in London’s West End| publisher=City of Westminster| url=http://transact.westminster.gov.uk/docstores/publications_store/Bespoke_tailoring_report_March_2006.pdf| date=March 2006| accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=BloomRent>{{cite web| title=London Tailor Shops Flee Savile Row as Offices Push Up Rents| author=Brian Lysaght| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aIWm6brPhG6w| publisher=Bloomberg| date=16 July 2006| accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> There were also criticisms from [[Giorgio Armani]] of falling behind the times.<ref name=Armani_FT>{{cite web| title=Big enough for the both of us?| author=James Sherwood| url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0d87dc8a-1e9f-11db-9877-0000779e2340,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F0d87dc8a-1e9f-11db-9877-0000779e2340.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer=#axzz3HQYyyKJF| publisher=The Financial Times| date=29 July 2006| accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=SR_Indep_2008>{{cite web| title=Savile Row: Slipping out of style?| author=Martin Hickman| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/incoming/savile-row-slipping-out-of-style-1057889.html| date=9 December 2008| accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref> However, since the [[2000s (decade)|mid-noughties]] Savile Row has been enjoying a remarkable resurgence, perhaps typified by the arrival of young and innovative tailors like [[Cad and the Dandy]], who have sought re-invigoration by means of modern technologies such as the internet.
The website [[GQ| GQ British]] featured an article in January 2018 about Savile Row.<ref name=GQ_2018>{{cite web| title=Savile Row tailors: the GQ Guide| author=Nick Carvell| url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/savile-row-tailors-london| publisher=Condé Nast Britain 2018| date=19 January 2018| access-date=23 June 2018}}</ref> It contains a list of SR tailors and states: "London is undeniably menswear’s global capital and the most important street in this world is Savile Row, a modest Mayfair row of the men’s tailors that quite simply make the best suits in the world."<ref name=GQ_2018/>
On the website Town and Country House, writer [[Dylan Jones]] is quoted in an article published in 2017 which is a guide to SR: "London is the home of menswear. We invented the suit, and in Savile Row we have the most important men’s shopping street in the world but we also have the very best in contemporary formal wear."<ref name=CTH_1>{{cite web| title=The C&TH Guide to Savile Row| author=Hollie Bell| url=https://www.countryandtownhouse.co.uk/style/savile-row| publisher=Country and Town House| date=2017| access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref>
==History ==
Tailoring has been associated with Savile Row since the 19th century, when [[Beau Brummell]], who epitomised the well-dressed man, patronised the tailors congregated on the Burlington Estate, notably around [[Cork Street]]. By 1803 some were occupying premises in Savile Row, but none of those original tailors survive today.
[[File:Gieves Hawkes 3178.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Gieves & Hawkes]] on No. 1 Savile Row]] The Savile Row Bespoke Association was founded in 2004 to protect and to develop bespoke tailoring as practised in Savile Row and the surrounding streets.<ref name=SRBA>{{cite web |url=http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/about-us/objectives/ |title=Objectives |publisher=Savile Row Bespoke Association |accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> Founder members include: Anderson & Sheppard, [[Dege & Skinner]], Gieves & Hawkes and Henry Poole. The member tailors are required to put at least 50 hours of hand labour into each two-piece suit.<ref name=SR_MemReq>{{cite web| title=Membership Requirements| url=http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/about-us/membership-requirements| publisher=Savile Row Bespoke Association| date=2014| accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref>
In a March 2006 report by the [[City of Westminster]] (Department of Planning and City Development), "Bespoke Tailoring in London’s West End", it was estimated that between 6,000 and 7,000 [[men's suit]]s were made in and around the Savile Row area annually.<ref name=SRT_Westminster_Plan/> This represented a turnover of approximately £21 million.<ref name=SRT_Westminster_Plan/> A [[Reuters]] article in February 2013 suggested that the total revenue for the informal group of suitmakers was now estimated to be £30-35 million pounds, with several tailoring houses having over 10% growth in recent years.<ref name=A&S_Reuters>{{cite web| title=Timeless suits from London's Savile Row back in fashion| author=Stephen Eisenhammer| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/02/20/uk-fashion-menswear-savilerow-idUKBRE91J0IY20130220| publisher=Reuters| date=20 February 2013| accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> The Fashion Industry's contribution as a whole to the British economy is an estimated £26 billion a year.<ref name=BBC_FB>{{ cite web| title=The Fashion Business| author=Linda Yueh| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-26257403?filter=none| publisher=BBC| date=19 February 2014| accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref>
As of August 2014, [[Government Pension Fund of Norway|Norway’s Oil Fund]], the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund, had acquired a 57.8 percent interest in the Pollen Estate.<ref name=SR_NYT_NOR>{{ cite web| title=Norway’s Oil Fund Buys London’s Savile Row| author=Stanley Reed| url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/11/norways-oil-fund-snaps-up-londons-savile-row/?_r=0| publisher=The New York Times| date=11 August 2014| accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> This includes properties in Mayfair, among which is Savile Row.<ref name=SR_NYT_NOR/>
In November 2016, SR became a Special Policy Area within the [[City of Westminster]]. This gives SR special planning status in order to safeguard its character: "Development in the Savile Row Special Policy Area will complement and enhance its role as an international centre of excellence for bespoke tailoring."<ref name=ES_SPA/><ref name=WCP/> See[[Savile_Row_tailoring#Westminster_Special_Policy_Area_2016| Westminster Special Policy Area 2016]].
===19th century===
{{main article| Henry Poole & Co}} *Henry Poole & Co are the acknowledged "Founders of Savile Row" and creators of the [[Tuxedo]]. The company has remained a family-run business since their establishment in 1806. They opened first in [[Brunswick Square]], in 1806, originally specialising in military tailoring, with particular merit at the time of the [[Battle of Waterloo]]. Their business moved to Savile Row in 1846, following the death of founder James Poole. In 1982, MD Angus Cundey brought the firm back to Savile Row (No. 15), after being in exile on Cork Street since 1961; Poole were forced to move to Cork Street, because the lease at number 32 expired and the unlisted building was demolished.
{{main article| Gieves & Hawkes}} *Gieves & Hawkes is a traditional British gentleman's bespoke tailor located at No. 1 Savile Row. The business dates from the late 19th century, and was formed by the merger of two separate businesses, 'Gieves' (founded 1785) and 'Hawkes' (founded 1771).<ref name=G&H_EL>{{cite web| title=Gieves and Hawkes at Number One Savile Row in London| url=http://www.elegant-lifestyle.com/gieves-and-hawkes.htm| publisher=Elegant Lifestyle (British Airways)| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> Starting out with roots from two suppliers who focused on the [[British Army]] and the [[Royal Navy]], it was the first Savile Row tailor to provide [[ready-to-wear]] clothes. There are various Gieves & Hawkes shops and concessions around the UK and in several other countries. It holds a number of [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal warrant of appointment]]s, which cover all three British Royal Warrants ([[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]], and HRH [[Charles, Prince of Wales]]).<ref name=G&H_WS>{{cite web| title=Gieves & Hawkes| url=http://www.gievesandhawkes.com| publisher=Gieves & Hawkes| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref>
{{main article| Dege & Skinner}} *Dege & Skinner (pronounced {{IPAc-en|'|d|iː|dʒ}}) is known for its expertise in military as well as civilian clothing. It remains a family-run business and celebrated its 150th anniversary in 2015. Located at No. 10 Savile Row, the firm was founded as J. Dege & Sons, and became a joint venture between the two families when William Skinner Jr. joined the firm in 1916. After the Skinner family took full ownership, the business was renamed Dege & Skinner, reopened by customer [[Colin Montgomerie]]. The company is by royal appointment to [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], His Majesty the [[List of rulers of Oman|Sultan of Oman]] and His Majesty the [[King of Bahrain]]. TRHs [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]] and [[Prince Harry]] can be seen wearing Blues & Royals uniforms made by the company in the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]].<ref name="alphacityguides">{{cite web|url=http://alphacityguides.com/london/articles/inside-savile-row|title=Inside Savile Row: A Chat With The World's Most Sought After Bespoke Tailors|publisher=alphacityguides inc.|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref>
Tailors Dege & Skinner made two frock coat uniforms worn by [[Prince Harry]] and [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge| Prince William]] at the [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle]] in May 2018.<ref name=HeSt>{{cite web| title=I made Prince Harry's wedding outfit| author=Henley Standard journalist| url=http://www.henleystandard.co.uk/news/home/126031/i-made-harry-s-outfit.html| publisher=Higgs & Co (Printers) Limited| date=28 May 2018| access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref><ref name=Reuters_RW>{{cite web| title=Prince Harry wears frock-coat uniform of the Blues and Royals for wedding| author=Reuters staff journalist| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-royals-wedding-harry/prince-harry-wears-frock-coat-uniform-of-the-blues-and-royals-for-wedding-idUSKCN1IK0D3| publisher=Reuters| date=19 May 2018| access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref> As well as the two uniforms, four outfits for the page boys were also created, challenging the tailors because of the boys size.<ref name=HeSt/> 8 weeks notice was given with very strict secrecy involved. When asked about any business opportunities that might be forthcoming from the wedding, Mr. Skinner said: "It’s difficult to say what effect it will have but the company has been mentioned in many forms of media in the last three or four days, so only time will tell".<ref name=HeSt/> He also said: "It helps us to keep focused on maintaining the skills and offering apprenticeships for making the clothes and keeping the business going for the next generation."<ref name=HeSt/>
*Davies and Son is an independent tailors on the West side SR, having started in Hanover Street in 1803.<ref name=Davies>{{ cite web| title=Davies & Son| url=http://daviesandsonsavilerow.com/index.html| accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> It moved to its current location in 1986, making it the oldest independent tailors on Savile Row.<ref name=Davies/> The brand incorporates a number of other tailoring businesses including: Bostridge and Curties and Watson, Fargerstrom and Hughes, Johns and Pegg, James and James, Wells of Mayfair and Fallan & Harvey.<ref name=Davies/> It is now owned by Alan Bennett, who stated in an interview: "It's difficult to attract new customers in Savile Row - it isn't generally a case of attracting passing trade. But I realised that by buying into other firms, where the owner might be approaching retirement age, I could add to my customer lists."<ref name=Bennett_SRSM>{{ cite web| title=Ken Austin and Alan Bennett| url=http://www.savilerow-style.com/tailors/tailors/benson_davies.htm| publisher=Savile Row Style Magazine| date=2008| accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> Davies & Son hold the Royal Warrant as Military Tailors to HRH The Duke of Edinburgh. Other customers have included: [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.]], [[Calvin Klein (fashion designer)|Calvin Klein]], [[Prince Michael of Kent]], [[Douglas Fairbanks Jr.]], [[Edward Fox (actor)|Edward Fox]], [[Clark Gable]], [[Benny Goodman]], [[Harry S. Truman]] and the [[Edward VIII|Duke of Windsor]].<ref name=Davies/> They have also clothed a large proportion of the crowned heads of Europe.<ref name=Davies/>
{{main article| H.Huntsman & Sons}} *Huntsman, a 163-year-old business, was taken over by Roubi L'Roubi and Pierre Lagrange in January 2013.<ref name=SR_ES_Hunts>{{cite web| title=Downton tailor sold to hedge fund star and his couture partner| author=Laura Chesters and Jonathan Prynn| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/downton-tailor-sold-to-hedge-fund-star-and-his-couture-partner-8444461.html| publisher=The Evening Standard| date=9 January 2013| accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> Roubi L'Roubi, is a British-born designer of Sudanese origin who is also couturier on New Bond Street, while Pierre Lagrange is a hedge fund investor from Belgium.<ref name=SR_ES_Hunts/> Huntsman has its roots in equestrian wear and this is a part of L'Roubi and Lagrange's country lifestyle.<ref name=SR_ES_R&L>{{cite web| title=Investment banking and Savile Row are not so different: Pierre Lagrange on owning and living the historic Huntsman brand| author=Charlotte Edwardes| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/investment-banking-and-savile-row-are-not-so-different-pierre-lagrange-on-owning-and-living-the-historic-huntsman-brand-9477353.html| publisher=The Evening Standard| date=3 June 2014| accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> L'Roubi explained to [[London Evening Standard]] that "rather than just owning the brand, we have a connection."<ref name=SR_ES_R&L/> He stated: “British upper-class fashion is about individuality. What we are wearing today is sombre but people wear tweeds and shooting stockings so bright that you’d never wear in the city, and that’s where the character comes out, in the high life."<ref name=SR_ES_R&L/> As well as the tailoring business, L'Roubi and Lagrange face challenges at Huntsman, including infrastructure updating.<ref name=SR_Spears>{{cite web| title=Huntsman's Roubi L'Roubi on fashion, physics and fitting in| author=Josh Spero| url=http://www.spearswms.com/news/huntsmans-roubi-lroubi-on-fashion-physics-and-fitting-in#.VHxbH2dybIX| publisher=Spear's magazine| date=23 July 2013| accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> Among the technology being used is an electronic tracer that produces a digital file and a hardcopy- this is for the extensive archive of more than 3000 clients and can be used when ordering ready-to-wear.<ref name=SR_Spears/> He stated to Spear's magazine that technology for ready-to-wear is not being used on SR. "The others are afraid of technology. We’re competing with Gucci, Ralph Lauren."<ref name=SR_Spears/> *[[Norton & Sons]] was established in the city of London in 1821, the firm moving to Savile Row in the middle of the 19th century. In the 1960s Norton's incorporated the other Savile Row firm of J. Hoare & E. Tautz. The firm were tailors to Sir Hardy Amies.<ref>The London Cut, Sherwood J., Marsilio Editori 2007</ref> Since 2005, the business has been run by the fashion designer and creative director [[Patrick Grant (designer)|Patrick Grant]].<ref name=PG_ft.com>{{cite web| title=Saïd fashions a tailor-made entrepreneur| author=Ian Wylie| url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/08f527f2-3b7f-11e0-9970-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1JTgTgf6i| publisher=TheFinancial Times| date=21 February 2011| accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> Grant is also known for his work with media, especially the [[BBC]]. The [[E. Tautz & Sons]] brand has been relaunched as ready-to-wear clothing and because of which, Grant was awarded the Menswear designer of 2010 at the [[British Fashion Awards]].<ref name=PG_ft.com/> Grant stated: "When you walk into our shop you get a sense that you’re walking into a place where people enjoy their work and take great pride in it."<ref name=PG_ft.com/> Previous clients include [[Edward VII]] and [[Winston Churchill]].<ref name=PG_ft.com/> *Kilgour & French. Founded in 1882 as T & F French in [[Piccadilly]], in 1923 French merged with existing Savile Row tailor A.H. Kilgour to form Kilgour & French. In 1925, Fred and Louis Stanbury joined the firm, and in 1937 the business changed its name to Kilgour, French and Stanbury. In 2003, the business became Kilgour. In 2013, Fung Group acquired Kilgour from JMH Lifestyle.<ref name=Kilgour_Fung>{{cite web| title=Fung Group acquires Savile Row's Kilgour| url=http://www.fashionunited.co.uk/fashion-news/fashion/fung-group-acquires-savile-rows-kilgour-2013092518585| date=25 September 2013| accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> At present, [[Carlo Brandelli]] is the Creative Director (he was CD between 2003 and 2009). He stated: "The first time I was here [at Kilgour], I contemporised. But this time I'm experimenting with what bespoke can be. Because a suit is still a form of armour, it tells everyone where you are in the hierarchy."<ref name=Kilgour_Carlo>{{cite web| title=The Return of the Native| author=Bill Prince| url=http://kilgour.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/GQ.pdf| date=October 2014| accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref>
===20th century===
*Anderson & Sheppard (A&S). In the early 20th Century, tailoring was softened by Frederick Scholte, a Dutchman, when he developed the [[Drape suit|English drape]] for the Duke of Windsor (later [[Edward VIII]]).<ref name=A&S_Davies>{{ cite web| title=Anderson & Sheppard, Savile Row Tailors |author=Angus Davies|url= http://www.escapement.uk.com/anderson--sheppard-savile-row-tailors.html| publisher=Escapement| date=21 August 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=Hill129>{{ cite book| last=Hill|first=D. D.|title=American Menswear: From the Civil War to the Twenty-First Century|year=2011|publisher=Texas University Press| location=Lubbock, Texas|pages=129–131}}</ref> Scholte's "dress soft" style was developed into the "London cut", the house style of A&S, by Peter Gustav, a protégé of Sholte.<ref name=A&S_Australian>{{ cite web| title=Anda Rowland guides Anderson & Sheppard into a new era of personal service| author=Jonathan Lobban| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/executive-living/luxury/anda-rowland-guides-anderson-sheppard-into-a-new-era-of-personal-service/story-e6frg8io-1227043947093?nk=d52b185a45e87ce5a35892c2cd653126| publisher=The Australian| date=5 September 2014| accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> The "London cut" is a high, small armhole with a generous upper sleeve that permits the jacket to remain close to the neck while freeing the arm to move with comfort.<ref name=A&S_Australian/> In 1906, Peter Gustav, also known as Per Anderson, founded A&S at No. 30, Savile Row.<ref name=A&S_Australian/>
In 2004, A&S' lease at No.30 expired, and the building's landlords wanted to raise its rent.<ref name=A&S_Conti>{{ cite web| title=Row and Behold| author=Samantha Conti| url=http://www.wmagazine.com/fashion/2008/03/anda_rowland| publisher=Wmagazine| date=March 2008| accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, Anda Rowland assumed A&S' daily operations.<ref name=A&S_Conti/> Rowland, daughter of entrepreneur [[Tiny Rowland]] (who had acquired A&S in the late 1970s, and whose family still holds an 80 per cent stake in the business) had been working at Parfums [[Christian Dior]] in Paris.<ref name=A&S_Australian/><ref name=A&S_Conti/> After Anda Rowland’s mother, Josie, decided to relocate A&S to its current, smaller premises on nearby Old Burlington Street, she appealed to her daughter for assistance in managing the firm.<ref name=A&S_Conti/> Before Anda's arrival, A&S did not operate a web site or viable computer network, costs were left unrecorded and approximately £500,000 worth of unpaid tailoring bills (money owed to A&S) had accrued.<ref name=A&S_Conti/> Rowland stated: "We’d been in the old buildings since the 1920s and, like many Savile Row tailors or traditional companies, your image becomes tied … like [[Harrods]], it becomes tied to the building."<ref name=A&S_Australian/>
Anda Rowland's initial act at A&S was to create an internet presence for the firm.<ref name=A&S_Australian/> A&S' website is a marketing tool and, says Rowland, “it helps to remind people or reinforces the idea that we have one foot in the past, but, also, one foot very much in today”. Since 2005, A&S' sales have risen exponentially so that, allowing for the hiring of six additional full-time apprentices, for a total of eight.<ref name=A&S_Australian/> As part of its 2012 revival, A&S opened a haberdashery shop on Clifford Street, at the end of the Row. Previous A&S customers include: [[Cary Grant]], [[Gary Cooper]], [[Fred Astaire]], [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Bryan Ferry]], [[Manolo Blahnik]] and [[Tom Ford]].<ref name=A&S_Australian/> In January 2013, HRH Prince Charles visited A&S.<ref name=Charles_And&Shep>{{cite web| title=A very Royal appointment: the Prince of Wales visits his tailor| author=Mick Brown| url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG9778740/A-very-Royal-appointment-the-Prince-of-Wales-visits-his-tailor.html| publisher=The Daily Telegraph| date=4 January 2013| accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> In the 30 years that A&S had tailored his suits and coats, HRH had never actually visited the company's premises.<ref name=Charles_And&Shep/> In 2012, A&S' revenues topped £4 million and its annual revenues have increased over 13 percent each year since 2009.<ref name=A&S_Reuters/> A&S manager Colin Heywood stated: "We're doing very well, actually. We've found that business has picked up in the last few years, and we couldn't be busier."<ref name=A&S_Reuters/>
*Welsh & Jeffries has premises at No. 20. It is owned by James Cottrell and includes the tailors Lesley & Roberts.<ref name=W&J_Website>{{cite web| title=Welsh & Jeffries| url=http://welshandjefferies.wix.com/welsh-and-jefferies| accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> It started in 1917 on the high street of [[Eton, Berkshire|Eton]] and became an established military tailor.<ref name=W&J_Website/> In 1990, H.R.H. the Prince of Wales confirmed Welsh and Jefferies pedigree as a military tailor when he appointed the firm with his Royal Warrant as sole military tailor.<ref name=W&J_Website/> They are an independent company. Owner James Cottrell started as an apprentice at the age of 16 in Kilgour French & Stanbury and trained there for 5 years.<ref name=W&J_Keikari>{{ cite web| title=Interview with James Cottrell| author=Ville Raivio| url=http://www.keikari.com/english/interview-with-james-cottrell| publisher=Keikari| date=14 May 2013| accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> He worked there as a coatmaker for 15 years before becoming a cutter at Tommy Nutter, from where he went to Henry Poole for 18 years.<ref name=W&J_Keikari/> He was invited to join Welsh & Jefferies as a partner in January 2007, and in February 2013 took over the business with Yingmei Quan as junior partner.<ref name=W&J_Website/> Yingmei Quan won the Golden Shears competition in 2011 which enhanced her reputation as one of the better female cutters on Savile Row.<ref name=W&J_Keikari/> Cottrell stated: "Finding your cutting style is a process that improves with your experience throughout the years by looking at people’s figures and trying to get a perfect line and balance for that person. That is what bespoke tailoring is all about."<ref name=W&J_Keikari/> *[[Chester Barrie]] was established in 1935 by expatriate English tailor Simon Ackerman, who wanted a British brand and tailoring for his New York-based clothing business. Locating its factory in [[Crewe]] from 1939, close to the [[Port of Liverpool]] and its cloth supplier in [[Huddersfield]], it introduced semi-bespoke and [[ready-to-wear]] tailoring to the row. Sold to [[Austin Reed (retailer)|Austin Reed]] in 1980, it went into receivership in 2002, which split the factory from the retail operation. Now owned by Prominent Europe, clients have included [[Cary Grant]] and [[Winston Churchill]], while both [[Steve McQueen]] and [[Sean Connery]] wore Chester Barrie in their films.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} *The British fashion house [[Hardy Amies (fashion house)|Hardy Amies]] was founded by English [[dressmaker]] [[Hardy Amies]] in 1946.<ref name="FashEncyc">{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/A-Az/Amies-Sir-Hardy.html|title=Hardy Amies|publisher=Fashion Encyclopedia|accessdate=2009-10-08}}</ref> Having been managing designer for [[Lachasse]] in 1934, and having designed clothes for the British Board of Trade under the government Utility Scheme, Amies bought the bombed out shell of No.14 Savile Row in 1946.
Amies was one of the first European designers to venture into the ready-to-wear market when he teamed up with [[Joseph Hepworth (tailor)|Hepworths]] in 1959 to design a range of menswear. In 1961, he made fashion history by staging the first men's ready-to-wear catwalk shows, at the Ritz Hotel in London<ref name="VicAlb">{{cite web| title=Fashion in Motion: Hardy Amies| url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/f/fashion-in-motion-hardy-amies| publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]]| date=April 2006| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Amies also undertook design for in-house work wear, which developed from designing special clothes for groups such as the [[Oxford University Boat Club]] and [[London Stock Exchange]]. Amies also designed costumes for films, including ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''.<ref name=Amies_IMDB>{{cite web| title=Hardy Amies| url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0024868| publisher=[[IMDb]]| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref>
Amies is perhaps best known to the British public for his work for [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]]. The association began in 1950, when Amies made several outfits for the then Princess Elizabeth's royal tour to Canada. Although the couture side of the Hardy Amies business was traditionally less financially successful, the award of a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal warrant of appointment]] as official dressmaker in 1955 gave his house a degree of respectability and resultant publicity. One of his best known creations is the gown he designed in 1977 for Queen Elizabeth's Silver Jubilee portrait which, he said, was "immortalised on a thousand biscuit tins."<ref name="FashEncyc"/> Knighted in 1989, Amies held the warrant until 1990, when he gave it up so that younger designers could create for the Queen.
In May 1973, Amies sold the business to [[Debenhams]], who had themselves purchased Hepworths which distributed the Hardy Amies line. Amies purchased the business back in 1981. In May 2001, Amies sold his business to the Luxury Brands Group. He retired at the end of that year, when [[Morocco|Moroccan]]-born designer Jacques Azagury became head of couture. In November 2008, after going [[bankruptcy]], the Hardy Amies brand was acquired by Fung Capital, the private investment arm of Victor and William Fung, who together control the Li & Fung group.<ref name=HA_Fung>{{cite web| title=Hardy Amies UK stores to close following sale to Fung Capital| author=Lisa Berwin| url=http://www.retail-week.com/hardy-amies-uk-stores-to-close-following-sale-to-fung-capital/1920101.article| publisher=Retail Week| date=11 November 2008| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> The current collection is overseen by design director Mehmet Ali. The Hardy Amies name is still licensed globally, particularly in Japan.
[[File:Beatles - Abbey Road.jpg| thumb| Tommy Nutter dressed three of the four Beatles on the cover of their album ''[[Abbey Road]]''.]] *Nutters of Savile Row was opened on [[Valentine's Day]] 1969 by [[Tommy Nutter]] and [[Edward Sexton]], who had worked together at Donaldson, Williamson & Ward.<ref name=Nutters_Open>{{ cite web| title=An article about the opening of the Nutters of Savile Row| url=http://www.edwardsexton.co.uk/the-tailor-and-cutter| publisher=Edward Sexton| date=February 1969| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> They were financially backed by [[Cilla Black]] and her husband Bobby Willis, Managing Director of the Beatles' [[Apple Corps]] [[Peter Brown (music industry)|Peter Brown]], and lawyer James Vallance-White.<ref>{{cite book| author=James Sherwood| title=The London Cut: Savile Row Bespoke Tailoring| publisher=Marsilio| date=2007| isbn=978-8831791557}}</ref> Nutters was the first shop on Savile Row to pioneer 'open windows' and had bold displays created by the then unknown [[Simon Doonan]], resulting in the shop helping modernise the perception of Savile Row.<ref>{{cite web|title = Fashion should be funny| author=Laura Burton| url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/sep/25/television.fashion| publisher=The Guardian| date=25 September 2008| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Nutters of Savile Row dressed the entire social spectrum from the [[Robin Russell, 14th Duke of Bedford|Duke of Bedford]] and [[Edward Douglas-Scott-Montagu, 3rd Baron Montagu of Beaulieu|Lord Montagu]], to [[Mayor of San Francisco]] [[Willie Brown (politician)|Willie Brown]], to [[Mick Jagger|Mick]] and [[Bianca Jagger]], [[Elton John]] and [[the Beatles]].<ref name=TN_Obit>{{cite web| title=Tommy Nutter obituary| url=http://www.edwardsexton.co.uk/tommy-nutter-article-3| publisher=The Independent On Sunday| date=5 March 2006| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Their designs included Bianca Jagger's wedding suit and the costumes for the [[Batman (1989 film)|1989 Batman film]] including those worn by [[Jack Nicholson]].<ref name=TN_Obit/> Tommy Nutter was proudest of the fact that the suits worn by three of the Beatles on the front cover of ''[[Abbey Road]]'' were made by Nutters.<ref name=Nutter_Obit>{{ cite web| title=Obituary: Tommy Nutter| author=Meredith Etherington-Smith |authorlink1=Meredith Etherington-Smith |publisher=The Independent| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-tommy-nutter-1541027.html| date=18 August 1992| accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> Nutter left the business in 1976 and went to work at Kilgour, leaving Edward Sexton to continue running the business.<ref name=Sherwood>{{ cite book| author=James Sherwood| title=Savile Row: The Master Tailors of British Bespoke| publisher=[[Thames & Hudson]]| date=11 October 2010| isbn=978-0500515242}}</ref> Nutter died from complications arising from [[HIV/AIDS]] on 17 August 1992 at the [[Cromwell Hospital]] in London.<ref name=Nutter_Obit/> Edward Sexton continues to work at his premises on [[Beauchamp Place]], [[Knightsbridge]].<ref name=Sexton_Current>{{cite web| title=Edward Sexton| url=http://www.edwardsexton.co.uk| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref>
Meredith Etherington-Smith wrote: "Nutter was a gentle humorist who had a wide and interesting circle of friends attracted by his enthusiasm, by his gentle, self-mocking personality and his acerbic comments on the vagaries of others, always ending with the expression 'But who am I to talk?'."<ref name=Nutter_Obit/>
*Chittleborough & Morgan was formed in 1981 when Joseph Morgan and Roy Chittlebrough left Nutters Of Savile Row, where they had worked with Edward Sexton, and opened their own shop. They produce only bespoke clothing with no ready-to-wear or made-to-measure.
===New generation=== {{anchor|New bespoke movement}} [[File:RJ 03.jpg|thumb|Backstage at the Richard James London Collections: Men runway show, 2012]] Modernisation, which had begun in 1969 with Nutters of Savile Row, had slowed by the early 1990s, so Savile Row tailors were "struggling to find relevance with an audience that had grown increasingly disassociated".<ref name=WeiKoh>{{cite journal| title=A Note From Our Founder| author=Wei Koh| publisher=The Rake| page=36| volume=3| issue=9| date=2010}}</ref> Three 'New Generation' designers are credited with keeping Savile Row ahead of the times: they were Ozwald Boateng, Timothy Everest (a former apprentice of Nutter's) and Richard James.<ref name=BBC_StyleGenius>{{ cite web| title=The New Generation of Modern Tailoring|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/britishstylegenius/content/21811.shtml| publisher=BBC| accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref> Having each broken away independently from the Savile Row mould, public relations professional Alison Hargreaves coined the term "New Bespoke Movement" to describe collectively the work of this "new generation" of tailors.<ref name=Arbuturian>{{cite web| title=Tinker, Tailor, Timothy Everest| author=Ash J. Lipkin| url=http://www.arbuturian.com/fashion/timothy-everest| publisher=The Arbuturian| date=30 April 2010| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Interest reached a peak in 1997 when the three were featured together in [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|''Vanity Fair'']].<ref name=Arbuturian/> The issue, entitled "Cool Britania", portrayed the tailors as the forefront of nineties style and design.<ref name=Vanity_Cool>{{cite web| title=London Swings! Again!| author=David Kamp| url=http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/archive/1997/03/london199703| publisher=Vanity Fair| date=March 1997| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=20th_Century>{{cite web| title=London Swings Again!| url=http://www.20thcenturylondon.org.uk/mol-97-98-1| publisher=20th Century London| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> The newcomers altered their shop fronts and utilised marketing and publicity to their advantage.<ref name=MadeInBritain>{{cite book| author=Catherine McDermott| title=Made in Britain: Tradition and Style in Contemporary British Fashion| pages=40–48| publisher=[[Mitchell Beazley]]| date=9 May 2002| isbn=978-1840005455}}</ref> For example, when [[Richard James (tailor)]] opened its Savile Row store in 1992, it introduced Saturday opening, something of a revolution to Savile Row at that time.<ref name=RJ_SatOpen>{{cite web| title=Savile Row Bespoke: 20th Century (post 1950)| url=http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/about-us/history/20th-century-post-1950| publisher=Savile Row Bespoke| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Eight years later in 2000, [[Richard James (tailor)]] opened a new shop with large plate glass windows that allowed customers to see inside.<ref name=Moreton>{{cite web|title=It's scissors at dawn in Savile Row| author=Cole Moreton| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/its-scissors-at-dawn-in-savile-row-710922.html| publisher=The Independent| date=13 August 2000| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref>
The new generation challenged the traditional Savile Row styling, bringing twists and "a fine sense of colour to bespoke suits."<ref name=Indy_JW>{{cite web| title=John Walsh: His dark materials| author=John Walsh| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/john-walsh-his-dark-materials-777624.html| publisher=The Independent| date=4 February 2008| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> They were seen to "push the envelope of modern suit making and bespoke active wear, creating more contemporary silhouettes with bolder fabrics."<ref name=BestLife>{{cite web| title=London Calling:Riding around a British tailor's bespoke world| author=Michael Slenske| url=http://business.highbeam.com/435924/article-1G1-192648416/london-calling| publisher=HighBeam Business| date=1 October 2008| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Unlike the older establishments, this new generation of tailors set out to garner celebrity clients, disseminate their products via supermarket chains and attract wider national and international custom, raising the profile of their new tailoring style.<ref name=MadeInBritain/> In 2001 [[Richard James (tailor)]] was awarded the title Menswear Designer of the Year by the [[British Fashion Council]], following that up in 2008 with the Bespoke Designer of the Year award, in recognition of its contribution to British tailoring.<ref name=LB_DT>{{cite web| author=Hilary Alexander| title=Luella Bartley wins 'Designer of the Year' at British Fashion Awards| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/3520107/Luella-Bartley-wins-Designer-of-the-Year-at-British-Fashion-Awards.html| publisher=The Daily Telegraph| date=November 2008| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> Boateng received the French Trophee de la Mode for Best Male Designer in 1996.<ref name=MadeInBritain/>
*[[Richard James (tailor)]] was founded in 1992 and was the first of the 'New Establishment' or [[New Bespoke Movement]] tailors of [[Savile Row]].<ref name=RJ_LS>{{cite news| author=Simon Mills| title=The tailors putting Savile Row back on the map| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/the-tailors-putting-savile-row-back-on-the-map-6576484.html| publisher=The London Evening Standard| date=March 2011| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> Richard James's tailoring has always centred on what has become known as its 'modern classic' style: one or two-button single-breasted suits with slightly longer, more waisted jackets, incorporating deep side vents and a slightly higher armhole to give a slim, definitive silhouette. The overall design philosophy is to produce classic clothing, but push the barriers through experimenting with fabrics and making bold use of colour. Indeed, the British fashion writer and academic [[Colin McDowell]] has described James himself as being "the best colourist working in menswear in London today".<ref name=RJ_DW>{{cite web| author=Design Week| title=Style icons| url=http://www.designweek.co.uk/news/style-icons/1126637.article| publisher=Design Week| date=July 2003| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=RJ_Indy>{{cite news| author=Roger Tredre| title=Style: Another Nutter on the Row: Richard James, like Tommy Nutter before him, is shaking up Savile Row with his range of designer clothes, says Roger Tredre| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/news/style-another-nutter-on-the-row-richard-james-like-tommy-nutter-before-him-is-shaking-up-savile-row-with-his-range-of-designer-clothes-says-roger-tredre-1555202.html| publisher=The Independent| date=October 1992| accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> *Four-time winner of the British Designer of the Year award [[Alexander McQueen]] [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] served an apprenticeship with Savile Row tailors Anderson & Sheppard, before joining Gieves & Hawkes.<ref name=AlMcQ>{{cite web| title=Alexander McQueen| url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/a/Alexander-McQueen| publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum| accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> He later joined the theatrical costumiers [[Angels and Bermans]].<ref name=AlMcQ/> McQueen went on to found the fashion house [[Alexander McQueen (brand)|Alexander McQueen]], from which the creative director [[Sarah Burton]] designed the dress worn by [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] during her wedding to [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]] in April 2011.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13236617 | publisher=BBC News | title=Royal wedding: What are they saying about the dress? | date=29 April 2011| accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> Alexander McQueen have a flagship store at Number 9, Savile Row for Bespoke and Made-to-Measure.<ref name=AlMcQ_Bespoke>{{cite web| title=Alexander McQueen| url=http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/experience/en/alexandermcqueen/store/#id_article=360| accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> *Ozwald Boateng, a pioneer of the new generation, saw himself as both tailor and a designer, coining the term "bespoke couturier".{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} Born in [[Ghana]] in the late 1960s and brought up in north London, Boateng started tailoring at age 16, selling his mother's designs on [[Portobello Road]]; by twenty three he had set himself up full-time in business. He began making bespoke suits in 1990, and is credited with introducing Savile Row tailoring to a new generation. The first tailor to stage a catwalk show in Paris, Boateng's many clients include [[Will Smith]], [[Jamie Foxx]], [[Samuel L. Jackson]], [[Dhani Jones]], [[Russell Crowe]], [[Keanu Reeves]], and [[Mick Jagger]].<ref>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/fashion/fashion_motion/ozwald_boateng/index.html Ozwald Boateng – Victoria and Albert Museum<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[LVMH]] President [[Bernard Arnault]] appointed Boateng Creative Director of Menswear at French Fashion house [[Givenchy]] in 2004.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2004/09/06/380345/index.htm | publisher=Fortune | first=Janet | last=Guyon | title=The Magic Touch LVMH chief Bernard Arnault runs dozens of luxury brands| date=6 September 2004| accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> His first collection was shown in July 2004 in Paris, at Hotel de Ville.<ref name=OB_FS>{{cite web| title=Ozwald Boateng| url=http://fashionsizzle.com/oswald-boateng| date=3 May 2013| accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> Boateng parted with Givenchy after the Spring 2007 collection.<ref name=OB_FS/> *Steed Bespoke Tailors was established in January 1995 by Edwin DeBoise, whose father and brother are both tailors, and [[Thomas Mahon (tailor)|Thomas Mahon]].<ref name=SR_Steed>{{cite web| title=Steed Bespoke Tailors| url=http://www.steed.co.uk/en| publisher=Steed Tailors| accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref> They are based in Savile Row and Cumbria making bespoke and semi bespoke suits with a range of braces, buttons and ties.<ref name=Steed_HF>{{cite web| title=Steed Tailors| url=http://www.hotfrog.co.uk/Companies/Steed-Tailors| publisher=Hotfrog| accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref> DeBoise trained at the [[London College of Fashion]], and then apprenticed under Edward Sexton, followed by seven years at Anderson & Sheppard, before founding the company Steed. 2002 was Steed's eighth year in business and one that saw an amicable split with Mahon, who is now with English Cut. In September 2008, Edwin's eldest son Matthew DeBoise joined the company and is learning the trade under his father.<ref name=SR_Steed/> *Richard Anderson was founded in 2001 by Richard Anderson and Brian Lishak who acquired Strickland & Sons (est. 1780) in 2004.<ref name="GQ">{{cite journal| author=Jamie Millar| date=19 July 2011| title=The GQ.com Savile Row guide| journal=GQ| publisher=Condé Nast UK|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/style/articles/2011-07/19/savile-row-bespoke-suits-best-tailors-london/viewall| accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> Richard Anderson is author of ''Bespoke: Savile Row Ripped and Smoothed'', his autobiographic account of being an apprentice tailor.<ref name="GQ"/> Anderson stated in a 2006 Financial Times article: "Bringing the traditional and the modern together is not something new to Savile Row, we have customers of all ages."<ref name=Armani_FT/> Customers have included [[Mick Jagger]], [[Bryan Ferry]] and [[the Black Eyed Peas]].<ref name=Armani_FT/> *Stowers Bespoke, established in 2006 by Ray Stowers, former head of bespoke at Gieves & Hawkes for 25 years, was created to reverse the trend in the modern market to mass-produce garments in the far east, with all ready to wear suits, accessories and made to measure suits in England.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} Originally working from 13 Old Burlington Street, in the spring of 2007 Stowers Bespoke was the lead brand when Liberty launched their formal wear room making [[Liberty (department store)]] the only department store to offer in-house bespoke tailoring.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} In September 2008 Stowers Bespoke purchased an established tailors James Levett, and is in the process of making their shop at 13 Savile Row the Stowers Bespoke flagship store. *[[Cad and the Dandy]] (C&D) is the latest addition to Savile Row tailoring.<ref name=Cad&Dandy>{{cite web| title=Cad & The Dandy| url=http://www.cadandthedandy.co.uk| C&D initially came to an arrangement with Chittleborough & Morgan to allow appointments in their shop. author=Timothy Barber| url=http://www.cityam.com/article/city-boys-offering-cut-above| publisher=CityAM| date=24 September 2010| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=G_Courvoisier>{{cite web| title=Courvoisier Future 500: Top 50| url=https://www.theguardian.com/courvoisier500/50-of-the-best-fashion| publisher=The Guardian| date=2009| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> In July 2010 the Britain’s bespoke tailoring industry facing an alarming shortage of master tailors, the company established an apprenticeship programme in London with young “would-be tailors” joining C&D's 22 staff members across its three London locations: Savile Row, Birchin Lane and [[Canary Wharf]].<ref name=C&D_Skills>{{cite web| title=Britain’s bespoke tailoring industry faces catastrophic skill gap| author=Business Matters| url=http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/columns/opinion/20966/britains-bespoke-tailoring-industry-faces-catastrophic-skill-gap| publisher=Business Matters| date=10 September 2013| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/festival-of-business/10219272/Cad-and-the-Dandy-tailor-made-for-our-times.html| publisher=The Daily Telegraph| date=4 August 2013| accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> In 2013, C&D entered the shoe market, buying the existing manufacturer Wildsmith, a 166-year-old business.<ref name=Tele_Aug2013/> C&D founders Sleater and Meiers are keen to complement Wildsmith’s “Made in Britain” credentials by eventually making all of its suits here, too. “Customers want quality, they want 'Made in England’, which is why we’re switching” stated Meiers.<ref name=Tele_Aug2013/> *In April 2016, the tailor Kathryn Sargent became the first woman to open a tailoring house in SR.<ref name=KSES_2016>{{cite news| title=Tailor to David Beckham and the royal family makes history as first woman to open shop on Savile Row| author=Jonathan Prynn| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/fashion/news/tailor-to-david-beckham-and-the-royal-family-makes-history-as-first-woman-to-open-shop-on-savile-row-a3218296.html| publisher=London Evening Standard| date=5 August 2016| access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=KSGuardian_2016>{{cite news| title=A cut above: first female master tailor opens shop on Savile Row| author=The Press Association| 2016}}</ref><ref name=KSBBC_2016>{{cite news| title=First female master tailor opens Savile Row shop| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-35977446| publisher=BBC| date=7 April 2016| access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref> Among those Sargent has dressed include royalty, actors, politicians and [[David Beckham]].<ref name=KSES_2016/><ref name=KSGuardian_2016/> The master tailor, who is originally from [[Leeds]], spent 15 years at nearby Gieves & Hawkes, rising through the ranks to be head cutter before opening her first store in Brook Street in 2012.<ref name=KSGuardian_2016/><ref name=KS_YP>{{cite news| title=Tailor maid: Cutting a dash in the rag trade| author=Sarah Freeman| url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/lifestyle/fashion/tailor-maid-cutting-a-dash-in-the-rag-trade-1-7392031| newspaper=[[The Yorkshire Post]]| date=9 August 2015| access-date=13 September 2016}}</ref> She said: "It feels wonderful to be on Savile Row, and like a real sense of achievement. It is just great to have your shop and your garments on display for people to see."<ref name=KSGuardian_2016/> "I am thrilled to be making history, although for me being a woman is incidental, I am a tailor first and foremost."<ref name=KSGuardian_2016/> Sargent is initially taking up a trial summer residency at number 37 until the end of August 2016 in the shop previously occupied by designer Nick Tentis.<ref name=KSES_2016/> She already runs an appointment-only tailoring house on Brook Street and said she would decide whether to continue permanently with the Savile Row shop at the end of the summer.<ref name=KSES_2016/> William Skinner, chairman of the Savile Row Bespoke Association, said: "It's fitting that the first woman to be appointed as a head cutter on Savile Row is returning to open a shop of her own and is testament to the continued appeal of Savile Row as the sartorial home of high quality, hand-crafted tailoring."<ref name=KSES_2016/>
In an interview with [[Another Magazine]] in 2012, Sargent stated: "Really I wanted to be a skilled worker rather than just a designer. I wanted to be able to fit something perfectly." Continuing, "If you know how things are made and know the potential possibilities, you can be more creative. Where else do you learn that except for Savile Row?"<ref name=KS_AnOther>{{cite web| title=Kathryn Sargent| author=Kin Woo|url=http://www.anothermag.com/current/view/2283/Kathryn_Sargent| publisher=AnOther| date=22 October 2012| accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> "Savile Row has changed so much – I was lucky to come in at a time when it was changing. Now I just want to concentrate on doing really good bespoke work and on making my own contribution to the history of the Row".<ref name=KS_AnOther/> When being interviewed by [[The Daily Telegraph]] in 2013, she observed: "Women know how to make men look good in suits - most men consult their wives or girlfriends or mistresses... Women are accepted in medicine and in law; why not tailoring? I hope equality will become so not an issue that soon we won't be able to believe that it ever was."<ref name=KS_TelFashion>{{cite web| title=Meet the women taking on Savile Row| author=Ellie Pithers| url=http://origin-fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG10433579/Meet-the-women-taking-on-Savile-Row.html| publisher=The Telegraph| date=9 November 2013| accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref>
*Manchester-born and former professional footballer William Hunt first opened on Savile Row in 1998, having had a shop on the [[King's Road]] in Chelsea.<ref name=WH_Journal>{{cite web| title=Interview: Fashion designer William Hunt| author=Liz Lamb| url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/news/north-east-news/interview-fashion-designer-william-hunt-4430801| publisher=[[The Journal (newspaper)|The Journal]]| date=29 June 2011| accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref> Based on a grounding of engineering, architecture and a love of Hollywood, his fiercely masculine designs, infused with splashes of colour, have become a success.<ref name=WH_Journal/> Hunt stated: "It’s an edgy, sexy label for ordinary guys... With the right attire there is no limit to a man's achievements."<ref name=WH_web>{{cite web| title=William Hunt| url=http://www.williamhunt.co.uk| accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref> His aim is to design powerful suits for powerful men.<ref name=WH_web/> Former clients include: [[Cristiano Ronaldo]], [[David Beckham]], [[Gary Neville]], [[Gordon Ramsay]] and [[Jonathan Ross]].<ref name=WH_web/> Since 2008, Hunt has expanded into golf, setting up The William Hunt Trilby Tour which is now widely regarded as the best amateur tournament in the UK.<ref name=WH_Journal/> *Whitcomb and Shaftesbury 2014}}</ref> Both had been working in New York but the brothers spotted “a gap in the market for high quality tailoring and quality advice”.<ref name=W&S_MsW/> The [[Chennai]]-born twins were able to lure Head Cutter John McCabe, a Savile Row stalwart having spent over 40 years cutting for the major names on the row.<ref name=W&S_MsW/> W&S's Savile Row Bespoke line is made in London, but they have another range, the relatively more affordable Classic Bespoke, which, while cut in London, is tailored in Chennai by handpicked craftspeople trained to Savile Row standards.<ref name=W&S_MsW/> W&S has two units in Chenai staffed by approximately 85 local craftspeople.<ref name=W&S_Hindu>{{ cite web| title=Suit dreams are made of these| author=Anusha Parthasarathy| name=W&S_Web>{{ cite web| title=Whitcomb and Shaftesbury| url=http://whitcombandshaftesbury.com/consciousness.html| publisher=W&S| accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> Former clients include [[Sachin Tendulkar]], Mick Jagger, Michael Jackson and [[Richard Gere]].<ref name=W&S_Hindu/> Mahesh stated: "The art of Savile Row is to create a three-dimensional form that drapes the body and shows ===Other companies on Savile Row===
*Established in 2002, Jasper Littman is based at 9 Savile Row, providing a visiting tailor service in South East England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thechapmagazine.co.uk/content/section_links/tailors.html|title=Bespoke and made-to-meausre Tailors|last=The Chap Magazine|work=The Chap|accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londontown.com/LondonInformation/Shopping/Jasper_Litman/ee3a/|title= London Directory London shopping Menswear |author=londontown|work=londontown.com|accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref> *[[John Lancaster (tailor)|John Lancaster]] is the founder of the experimental British clothing label [[VS Mono]]. (No. 13); Hidalgo Bros. (No. 13); James Levett (No. 14); Stuart Lamprell (No. 18); [[Maurice Sedwell]] (No. 19); Gary Anderson (No. 34/35); Alexandre: owned by British Menswear Brands (No. 39); 40 Savile Row (No.  40); *The oldest tailors in London, [[Ede & Ravenscroft]], have a premises close by on [[Burlington Gardens]]. *Gaziano & Girling (G&G) have become the first shoemakers on Savile Row at number 39.<ref name=Gaz&Gir>{{ cite web| title=Gaziano & Girling| url=http://www.gazianogirling.com/pages/savile-row| accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> They forged G&G in 2006, having been shoemakers in [[Northamptonshire]].<ref name=G&G_A&H>{{ cite web| title=Refined Aesthetics: Gaziano & Girling| author=Thierry Augustin| url=http://www.aandhmag.com/refined-aesthetics-gaziano-girling| publisher=A&H Magazine| date=October 2014| accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> Dean Girling, in an interview with A&H magazine, stated: "With our combined experience, we knew that we were entering a competitive and very niche market at this price point but we also knew we could produce a shoe that appealed to an equally unique customer base."<ref name=G&G_A&H/>
===Conduit Street tailors=== *Established by Austrian tailor Jonathan Meyer at 36 Conduit Street in the late 18th century, Meyer & Mortimer supplied both the [[Prince regent]] and his fashion mentor, Beau Brummell, as early as 1800. When the Prince became [[George IV of the United Kingdom]] he awarded the company a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal warrant of appointment]] which, through [[Queen Victoria]] and monarchs since, it still holds today. After Meyer pioneered modern trouser design in the 19th century, he formed a new company with Mortimer in Edinburgh, called the Royal Clan Tartan Warehouse.{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} After being bombed out of its premises during World War 2, the company relocated to its current location at 6 Sackville Street.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.meyerandmortimer.co.uk|title=Meyer & Mortimer| publisher=Meyer & Mortimer| accessdate=13 March 2011}}</ref> *In the late 1950s, from his premises at No.43 Conduit Street, Anthony Sinclair created a classic, pared down shape, which became known as the Conduit Cut.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-video/#v1780389696001| title=2012 Olympic Style Report| work=Harper's Bazaar}}</ref> Sean Connery famously adopted the look in 1962 for the first James Bond film, [[Dr. No (film)|''Dr. No'']], and continued to wear Sinclair suits for all of his appearances as Bond.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2012/07/06/designing-007-james-bond-exhibition-preview---barbican| title=The Name's Bond| work=Vogue|date=6 July 2012}}</ref> The business now operates from No. 6 Sackville Street. Though it is sometimes reported that [[Ian Fleming]] and his character [[James Bond]] bought suits on Savile Row, there is no evidence for this in the books.<ref name=Empire>{{cite web |url= http://www.empireonline.com/features/bond/bond-up-your-life |title=Empire Features |author=Empire |work=empireonline.com| accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=Spaiser>{{cite web |url= http://thesuitsofjamesbond.com/?cat=52 |title=Literary Bond | The Suits of James Bond |author=Matt Spaiser |work=thesuitsofjamesbond.com |year=2011 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=MFM>{{cite web |url= http://www.mensfashionmagazine.co.uk/style-icon-james-bond |title=Style Icon: James Bond | Mens Fashion Magazine |author=Laura Peta Ellis |work=mensfashionmagazine.co.uk |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
==Future== As of November 2014, there are only two family-owned tailoring houses left on Savile Row, namely Dege & Skinner and Henry Poole & Co.<ref name=KarlWest>{{cite web| title=Savile Row tailor fears overseas threat to rich tapestry of tradition| author=Karl West| url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2014/nov/14/savile-row-tailoring-foreign-buyout-threat-hong-kong| publisher=The Guardian| date=14 November 2014| accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> Managing Director of D&S William G. Skinner, when interviewed by The Business of Fashion (BofF) website, stated: "Ready-to-wear has been available on the Row for some time, but recession and a tough economic climate have led some retailers further down the road of ready-to-wear..."<ref name=BofFPt2>{{cite web| title=A Row of Opportunity, Part 2| author=Robin Mellery-Pratt| url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/01/row-opportunity-part-2.html| publisher=The Business of Fashion| date=29 January 2014| accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> Although in recent years the global luxury menswear market has grown at roughly double the pace of luxury womenswear, the tailors of Savile Row face the stark reality that bespoke tailoring is simply not a scalable business.<ref name=BofFPt1>{{cite web| title=A Row of Opportunity, Part 1| author=Robin Mellery-Pratt| url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/01/row-opportunity-part-1.html| publisher=The Business of Fashion| date=28 January 2014| accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>
How different companies compete in the forthcoming years will vary. Starting with the 150-year-old company Dege & Skinner, William Skinner points out the young people involved: the future generation of tailors, serving apprenticeships within the trade.<ref name=KarlWest/> He stated in an interview to [[The Guardian]]: "That highlights our belief in the future of the bespoke tailoring business. We have invested in the future of the trade, because we are confident about the future of the trade. We have a good business model; we make money and we reinvest it in the company. We are not a museum piece by any means."<ref name=KarlWest/> He continued: "A lot of people don’t want to go into a high street shop, they want the relationship and the service that we give. As long as we can maintain that, there’s every chance of surviving."<ref name=KarlWest/>
At Gieves & Hawkes (G&H), founded in 1771, the approach differs. In 2012, G&H was bought up by Trinity Ltd., part of Hong Kong's Fung Capital, the private equity partnership of Victor and William Fung, the chairman and group managing director of Li & Fung, the world’s largest supplier to consumer brands of clothing.<ref name=BofFPt1/> Ray Clacher, Chief Executive of G&H, stated in an interview to The BofF: "In the last 12 months, we have [become] a more style-driven, less suit-dependent company than we have been in the past... We have hired in excess of 40 new heads just to look after design, production and development and merchandising."<ref name=BofFPt1/> He continued: "We have opened seventeen stores and we have certainly spent over £10 million in terms of pure hardware — going into digital, websites for Japan, China, the UK."<ref name=BofFPt1/>
Patrick Grant, designer and owner since 2005 of bespoke tailor Norton & Sons and its sister ready-to-wear line E. Tautz, stated to The BofF : "The simple truth is that there are opportunities to sell ready-to-wear clothes thanks to Savile Row’s history."<ref name=BofFPt1/> He continued: "Personally as someone who has a business on both sides, I would like to see anything with a Savile Row name on it actually made on Savile Row... If you have got ten thousand suits being made by hand on Savile Row, but you have got a million suits somewhere in a factory in Asia also called Savile Row, I don’t think it can do anything other than hurt the business here."<ref name=BofFPt2/>
Kilgour & French was taken over by the company '14 Savile Row', a subsidiary of Fung Capital, in 2013.<ref name=TG_Brandelli>{{ cite web| title=The Savile Row saviour| author=Nick Compton| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/mens-style/45665/the-savile-row-saviour.html| publisher=The Daily Telegraph| date=21 September 2014| accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref> 14 Savile Row also owns Hardy Amies and Norman Hartnell. They managed to re-install Carlo Brandelli as Creative Director, who had resigned when Kilgour was taken over by in 2008 by [[JMH Group|JMH Lifestyle]].<ref name=TG_Brandelli/> According to Brandelli, Savile Row has been invigorated, but he stated to [[The Daily Telegraph]]: "It has changed over the last few years but it is still not enough." He continued: "Too many of the tailors are like the wrong kind of museum."<ref name=TG_Brandelli/>
Huntsman's Roubi L’Roubi is adamant that ready-to-wear is crucial to the survival of the Row.<ref name=SR_Economia>{{cite web| title=Savile Row Uncut| author=Laura Powell| url=http://economia.icaew.com/life/september-2014/savile-row-uncut| publisher=economia| date=5 September 2014| accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref> He stated to the website Economia: "There’s a way of carrying the traditions and modernising. They are not mutually exclusive."<ref name=SR_Economia/> He also broaches the subject of the dwindling proportion of female customers: today it accounts for less than 5% at Poole, Huntsman and Gieves & Hawkes.<ref name=SR_Economia/> He states: "It’s because women want instant purchases. They want to buy it, take it home and wear it that evening."<ref name=SR_Economia/> At present, the companies that advertise as bespoke tailors for women include: Nooshin, Katherine Maylin, King & Allen and Kathryn Sargent.
Henry Poole & Co. are wanting to expand into China.<ref name=SR_CNBC>{{ cite web| title=China the perfect fit for London’s $6,000 luxe tailors| author=Arjun Kharpal| url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/101905712| publisher=CNBC| date=25 August 2014| accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> In an interview with [[CNBC]], Simon Cundey, director of Henry Poole & Co, stated: "We've had a number of customers who have ordered in London and want the attention to detail we offer them and we hope that by bringing that option to Beijing we can grow the market there."<ref name=SR_CNBC/> Henry Poole & Co already has two stores in China through a partnership; however tailors make the framework for the suit in London and send it over to be assembled in a Chinese factory.<ref name=SR_CNBC/>
==Westminster Special Policy Area 2016==
In November 2016, SR was given special planning rules within the [[City of Westminster]] by the introduction of 'Special Policy Areas'.<ref name=ES_SPA>{{cite news| title=Savile Row gets tailor-made rules to safeguard its unique character| author1=S. Sleigh| author2=J. Prynn| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/savile-row-gets-tailormade-rules-to-safeguard-its-unique-character-a3392036.html| publisher=The Evening Standard| date=10 November 2016| access-date=5 February 2018}}</ref> These new planning rules include four other areas and will "make it far harder for developers and landlords to dilute their distinctive character by allowing “clone” chain stores to force out smaller independent businesses."<ref name=ES_SPA/> Mark Henderson of G&H and chairman of SR Bespoke Association is quoted as saying "I’m absolutely delighted. It’s recognition that Savile Row is totally unique."<ref name=ES_SPA/>
Westminster policy 'CM2.3: Savile Row Special Policy Area' states: "The Savile Row Special Policy Area (SPA) is home to a historic concentration of bespoke tailoring, with the street name in itself acting as a widely recognised international brand, synonymous with the unique and high quality bespoke and discreet, personal service it offers."<ref name=WCP>{{cite web| title=Westminster's City Plan| url=https://www.westminster.gov.uk/westminsters-city-plan-strategic-policies| publisher=The City of Westminster| pages=42-44| date=November 2016| access-date=5 February 2018}}</ref> It also states: "Encouraging bespoke tailoring uses in the Savile Row SPA will continue to support this cluster of bespoke tailoring activities and the wider bespoke tailoring industry in Westminster and the UK."<ref name=WCP/>
Councillor Robert Davis said: "Like a good suit, planning policy should be made to measure."<ref name=FN_1>{{cite web| title=Savile Row granted protection from Westminster City Council| author=Barbara Santamaria| url=http://uk.fashionnetwork.com/news/Savile-Row-granted-protection-from-Westminster-City-Council,752252.html| publisher=Fashion Network| date=11 November 2016| access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref> Also: "We are using our powers to protect some of the capital’s most valuable assets and create environments where specialist traders can thrive."<ref name=FN_1/>

{{orphan|date=December 2016}} The '''Throne Celebration in Morocco''' is a national occasion celebrated on 30 July of each year, punctuated by several official and popular celebrations, it commemorates the day of the King's accession to the throne. The first celebration was held in 1933 to recognise the accession of [[Mohammed V of Morocco]] in 1927.<ref>{{Cite book |title=A History of Modern Morocco |last=Miller |first=Susan Gilson |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2013 |isbn= 9781139619110 |page=131}}</ref> The current King [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI]] succeeded his father on 23 July 1999 and officially took the throne on 30 July. On the occasion, several nationwide events are covered on public television, including official activities.
== History == The first celebration was in 1933 in honour of King [[Mohammed V of Morocco|Mohammed V]], and was thereafter held on November 18 each year. The date moved to March 3 during the rule of the late King [[Hassan II]] (1961-1999). When King [[Mohammed VI]] took the throne in 1999, it moved again to July 30.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://aglobalworld.com/holidays-around-the-world/morocco-throne-feast/|title=Morocco Festively Celebrates Feast of the Throne|website=aglobalworld.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref>
== Throne Speech == The '''Throne Speech''' is given on the 30 July, when the King addresses the nation on official State TV, giving an inventory of events and projects completed during the previous year, and discusses the future vision and foreign policies of the kingdom. According to Article 52 of the [[Constitution of Morocco]] of 2011, the King has to address both the nation and parliament in order to make the Throne Speech binding to the nation and to the authorities.
